title: 107_hr2512
content: Authorization of appropriations for United States Customs Service for enhanced activities along the Southwest border. Authorization of appropriations for the United States Customs Service to enhance border investigative resources, combat drug smuggling and money laundering, process cargo efficiently, reduce traffic waiting times, and keep primary lanes open during peak hours at Southwest border ports. Appropriations include $467,320,000 for fiscal year 2002, $417,832,000 for fiscal year 2003, and necessary sums for subsequent fiscal years. In fiscal year 2002, $158,320,000 is allocated for acquiring narcotics enforcement, cargo processing, and counterterrorism technology along the Southwest border. This includes funds for mobile truck gamma ray systems, high energy pallet gamma ray systems, and higher energy truck x-ray upgrades. In fiscal year 2002, funding is allocated for various equipment and programs along the Southwest border, including high energy pallet gamma ray systems, higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, inspection technology maintenance, Industry Partnership Programs expansion, canine kennel construction, replacement of canines, automated targeting systems maintenance, x-ray vans, and tool trucks. In fiscal year 2002, funding is allocated for various equipment and programs along the Southwest border, including automated targeting systems maintenance, x-ray vans, tool trucks, contraband detection kits, surveillance camera systems, truck license plate reader systems, narcotics particle detectors, and land border vehicle targeting systems. In fiscal year 2002, funding is allocated for various equipment and programs along the Southwest border, including narcotics particle detectors, land border vehicle targeting systems, under vehicle inspection systems, outbound passenger facilities, work station replacements, Customs Automated Operations System lane installations, explosive vapor trace detectors, radiation pager detectors, radiation identification devices, and radiation and explosive detection. In fiscal year 2002, funding is allocated for various equipment and programs along the Southwest border, including narcotics particle detectors, land border vehicle targeting systems, under vehicle inspection systems, outbound passenger facilities, work station replacements, Customs Automated Operations System lane installations, explosive vapor trace detectors, radiation pager detectors, radiation identification devices, and radiation and explosive detection. For fiscal year 2003 and beyond, $15,832,000 annually is allocated for maintenance and support of equipment and training personnel for radiation detection equipment. The Commissioner of Customs may use funds for technologically superior equipment that achieves the same results at a cost equal to or less than specified equipment. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds to obtain equipment that achieves the same results at a lower cost than specified equipment. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $79,000,000 and $172,000,000 respectively will be allocated for increasing staff at the Southwest border to reduce waiting times and enhance drug enforcement efforts. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $230,000,000 each year will be allocated for improving Customs Service facilities at ports of entry on the Southwest Border. The authorization includes funding for the construction, improvement, and expansion of Customs Service facilities at ports of entry on the Southwest Border. The amounts authorized are in addition to any other appropriations for the United States Customs Service by law.
